ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned about the different strategies of hedge funds, bond pricing, options, credit default swaps, spreads, and a lot of other finance content. The course was pretty balanced between conceptual discussions of finance and financial instruments/strategies as well as more mathematical calculations of how pricing and valuation works.
I learned many hedge fund strategies as well as how to think about situations that seem like arbitrages but in fact, are not (limits to arbitrage).
Learned financial math.

Learned about arbitrage opportunities from mergers, activism, forwards, SPACs, different types of funds. Learned about pricing of many derivatives. Learned how to conduct economic and financial analysis
I learned many concepts throughout this course.  I learned how to look for arbitrage opportunities, price options and bonds, and studied several investment vehicles.
I learned about stocks, bonds, CDS, options, important m&a deals, corporate governance, and a lot of other financial jargon I had NO idea about before.
Learned a lot about different financial concepts and how they apply in the real world. Learned different mathematical approaches to valuing financial derivatives and finding arbitrage opportunities
I learned about the limits of arbitrage.

I learned a lot about asset pricing, corporate structure, and how arbitrage is the basis for how we value pretty much everything, even though a lot of the time we're basing the equations we use on finger-in-the-air quality assumptions.
Current topics in finance, arbitrage opportunities in mergers, IPOs, and carve outs.
I learned about financial concepts such as merger arbitrage, options, bonds, cds, spacs, etc

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Great professor. The course is disorganized however.

Pascutti is a funny and engaging professor for content that would otherwise be a little bit dense and potentially uninteresting. He routinely asks for feedback on topics/areas students want to see in class and is very receptive to feedback in that way. Keep in mind that the class isn't incredibly organized in the sense that lectures often diverge from prepared content, which some people may like and others may not. The quizzes, which make up a majority of your grade, can be pretty challenging, but they're not impossible. It's a bit difficult to know where you stand in the class gradewise. Pascutti doesn't care about grades, but that can make it hard to do well/get an A if that's your goal. If that's not your goal and you just want to learn, this is a good class for you, but make sure you're interested in the content, because it's very much a finance-driven class for people who want to go into/are already going into finance.
Professor Pascutti tells great stories and is extremely knowledgeable. That said, the course is a bit disorganized.
Strengths - Professor kept it really. Weakness - you really had to already know most content.

Weakness was that online notes were unorganized so going to class was totally necessary

Strength was that professor was super approachable and totally cared about the subject and student learning. Feedback was frequent and helpful and the course was adjusted to current events and student interests

I loved the free nature of the course.  I felt like the syllabus was very flexible, allowing us to focus on timely subjects.  I think that the course could do a better job of matching what we learned in lecture with the notes posted on canvas.  It sometimes felt like we were studying two different sets of notes.

This course is difficult and assumes prior knowledge in finance or corporate finance. I had none of that, but I learned ALOT with spending a lot of time reviewing the lecture recordings/notes and google. I appreciated that the professor was always open to all kinds of questions and the TA, Tianhao, was always so helpful in section. 

Strengths: the quizzes reflected class discussion and power point notes, and overtime reflected problem sets. I liked that the professor took feedback from students and adapted classes to review difficult concepts as well as make the quizzes more representative of what we were expected to know from the psets. The quizzes were hard tho, but I think the TA was fair in grading. The psets are pass/fail which also made them less stressful. The professor is also very funny and personable, which made class enjoyable. 

Weaknesses: the professor is a bit disorganized in lecture, ie. switches from class notes to powerpoint notes, to math on the board which was a bit hard to follow and use to study for the quizzes/homeworks. It would have been nice when he told us where he was switching to so we can note it down, or maybe stick to one method

Strengths was that we were tested and had problem sets throughout so you knew where you stood with the material. 
Weaknesses were that the material didnt follow an exact path and sometimes was hard to follow because one class may not lead into the next.
I thought the class was well taught. It could be improved by adding class notes of the real world current event tangents that are discussed in class to make preparing for the exam easier.

I think all of the topics are taught well, but you really have to dive deep into the problem sets to fully understand the nuances of everything. There are definitely not enough examples in lecture to cover everything. I think a little bit more of a defined structure to the course would also be a benefit; the topics all sort of blended together with no real order or progression.
Lectures and material on tests were often misaligned.

Strengths: great lectures, straightforward exams

Weaknesses: lots of midterms (4)
You learn a lot of finance skills but you have to put in a LOT of work if you dont have the background

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I would recommend this course to a student who knows they are interested in finance and already have a little bit of a background in finance; otherwise, I think you wouldn't enjoy the class.

I'd recommend this course to anyone interested in finance. A lot of people in the class were clearly very well-versed in finance which could be intimidating, but I think as someone with no prior finance internships I was able to learn a lot.
Yes if they want to work in finance

Totally would recommend if interested in non-banking finance. Teacher is so cool and passionate and funny. Lectures were extremely fun and interactive. Easily one of my favorite courses I'd ever taken. Hearing unfiltered opinions from a pro hedge fund founder was really helpful. Gave opinions on working in finance and spoke about dark side of the profession
I would highly recommend this course to anyone interested in a career in finance.

Yes! Definitely take this course if you have an interest in finance or plan on working in finance post grad. Its a practical course that you can apply to the real world (not many Econ senior seminars are). It might be easier if you have finance background or took corporate finance before because a lot of the information is assumed you've seen it before with the equations and concepts etc. Though if you do not have any of that experience and still want to take this class (like me), be prepared to work hard because you're going to have to do a lot of self learning and googling your way through this course because a lot of jargon is used and it gets pretty overwhelming at times. This course is also heavily white male dominated so... pls take it if you're a woman/POC and ask questions!! The prof and TA are really helpful and personable and encourage dumb questions (I asked a ton bc I was always confused). Review the psets and the handouts to prepare for the quizzes and you should be fine.
Yes if youre looking to learn more about certain financial concepts related to arbitrage
I would recommend this class to students who have a strong interest in finance.

I think if you are interested in finance this course is taught pretty well and covers a lot of good topics. Make sure that you take notes on everything though, not just the problems but also the real world examples and conceptual ideas, because those will also be tested in addition to calculations. Also do all the readings; not only are you graded on submitting a summary, but those are also fair game for quizes.
Yes, definitely.
This is a great course if you want to learn more practical finance skills. If you havent taken any other finance classes though be prepared to put in a lot of work
